Aerobic oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene over cobalt and manganese supported hexagonal mesoporous silicas as heterogeneous catalysts Wei hua Yu a ⁎ Chun hui Zhou b Dong shen Tong b Tian ning Xu a a Zhijiang College, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310024, PR China b Research Group for Advanced Materials & Sustainable Catalysis (AMSC), College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310014, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 751 88320062; fax: +86 751 88320062. Graphical abstract Highlights ► The catalytic system for aerobic oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene has been employed. ► The heterogeneous catalysts in combination with NHPI have been developed. ► The catalyst gives high conversion of 4-t-butyltoluene and selectivity to aldehyde. ► The catalyst exhibits easy recovery, and steady reuse. ► The mechanism for oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene has been developed. Monometallic cobalt and manganese, and their bimetal-supported hexagonal mesoporous silicas (HMS) prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation using cobalt nitrate and manganese acetate as precursors, and ethanol and ethylene glycol as impregnation solvents, respectively, were examined as catalysts for partial oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene with dioxygen as oxidizing agent in acetonitrile solvent. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm, diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy and thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis. The introduction of cobalt oxides to HMS kept complete mesostructure of HMS supports, high specific surface areas and big pore volumes. The dominant phase of Co3O4 was detected in the Co–HMS materials calcined at 550°C. A mixture of manganese oxides (MnO, Mn2O3, Mn3O4) was dispersed on the Mn–HMS catalysts after calcination at 550°C in the air. The bimetal-supported Co–Mn–HMS with loading 4wt.% of Co and Mn exhibited the best catalytic performance in the oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene with O2, and gave a conversion of 43.7% of 4-tert-butyltoluene and maximal yield of 27.4% of 4-tert-butylbenzaldehyde in a reaction time of 5h in liquid phase under mild condition. A high concentration and dispersion of M2+ (Co2+, Mn2+) and M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) ions on catalysts were responsible for high catalytic performance in the oxidation reaction via a free-radical chain promoted by N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI). The four consecutive cycles revealed that the cobalt and manganese species supported on HMS provided a possibility for the heterogeneous oxidation reaction. Keywords Cobalt Manganese Mesoporous silica 4-tert-Butyltoluene Oxidation 1 Introduction The selective oxidation of toluene derivatives into the corresponding oxygen-containing compounds such as aldehydes, alcohols and carboxylic acids is an area of considerable industrial importance and academic interest. In particular, the selective oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene to 4-t-butylbenzaldehyde is of high interest since the aldehyde is a valued intermediate for the production of fragrances, medicines, agricultural pesticides and especially, 4-tert-butyl-methyldihydrocinnamaldehyde for use in the cosmetics industry [1–5]. The industrial production of 4-tert-butylbenzaldehyde is carried out mainly by oxidation 4-tert-butyltoluene over MnO2 and H2SO4 catalysts [6]. It would be desirable to develop a more eco-friendly catalytic technology for this conversion because these industrial catalysts have environmental and processing disadvantages. Several studies have been reported as alternative pathways for the oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene to 4-tert-butylbenzaldehyde, including electrolysis and hydrogen peroxide or dioxygen or air oxidation in the gas or liquid phase [7–10]. Aerobic oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene to 4-t-butylbenzaldehyde in the presence of homogeneous Co(OAc)2/Mn(OAc)2/NaBr catalyst system in water–dioxane medium at 5.6MPa and 150°C afforded 87% selectivity at 16.4% conversion [3]. It has been reported that the H2O2 oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene at 45°C to the corresponding aldehyde gave a selectivity of 80% at 25–30% conversion over homogeneous Co(OAc)2/NaBr catalyst system [11]. The expensive cerium (IV) acetate in the presence of bromide has been reported to catalyze the H2O2 oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene with 59% selectivity at 41% conversion [4]. The photolytic H2O2/HBr route afforded higher conversion of 4-tert-butyltoluene and more by-products [5]. These homogeneous cobalt catalysts lead to unacceptable levels of losses in the catalyst recovery, recycling and operations [12], and bromide, which corrodes expensive titanium reactors and forms CH3Br(g), which can deplete the ozone layer, is, however, an undesirable component [13]. In the last decade, a new derivative, N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI), has been reported as an effective catalyst for CH activation by hydrogen abstraction in many oxidation reactions [14–17] including the oxidation of toluene derivatives [18,19]. However, a high selectivity is even harder to obtain because the corresponding products are usually more reactive so that it is difficult to stop at the corresponding alcohols or aldehydes [15,20]. For example, a conversion of 83% was obtained using O2 and NHPI promoted soluble Co(OAc)2 as the catalyst in CH3CN, but the selectivity to the desired aldehyde was only 4% in oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene [8]. A significant amount of experimental and numerical work has been performed on partial oxidation of toluene derivatives. Minisi et al. [21] reported the selective oxidation of toluene to benzylic alcohol by using a NHPI/I2 system. In order to avoid peroxidation and to recover the catalyst of NHPI, Rajabi et al. [19] used the immobilized NHPI on mesoporous silicas in combination with supported Co(II) as heterogeneous catalyst in the oxidation of methylaromatics and obtained higher reactivity and unusual selectivity to the benzaldehydes. Comparatively, from an industrial point of view, dioxygen oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene over heterogeneous catalysts is more attractive due to its low cost if the reaction can be carried out at lower temperature and atmospheric pressure. Cobalt and manganese complexes are widely used in oxidation of alkylaromatics as both a hetero and homogeneous catalyst because of their oxidation–reduction property and ability to demonstrate several valencies (Co: 2+, 3+; Mn: 2+, 3+, 4+ and 7+) with easy electron transfer between these states [22–24]. It is known that Co and Mn heterogeneous catalysts such as Co or Mn supported mesoporous materials [25,26], layered double hydroxides [27] and clays [28] have been achieved in many alkylaromatics oxidation reactions. So, we attempt to develop Co and Mn heterogeneous catalysts used in partial oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene on basis of success of the earlier literatures for getting rid of some disadvantages of environment pollution, unsafety and losses in the catalyst recovery, recycling and operations caused by homogeneous catalyzed systems. In the present work, we have investigated the properties of cobalt and manganese supported mesostructured silicas as catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation using cobalt nitrate and manganese acetate as precursors, and ethanol and ethylene glycol as impregnation solvents for the liquid phase oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene to 4-tert-butylbenzaldehyde using NHPI as free radical promoter and molecular oxygen as oxidizing agent. We have selected hexagonal mesoporous silicas (HMS) with 3D wormhole structure possessing a large surface area and a very small elementary particle domain size with shorter channels for reactants to access the active sites and for products to move out in order to avoid further oxidation [29,30]. We used organic ethanol and ethylene glycol as impregnation solvents in favor of mesostructure of HMS silicas and dispersion of cobalt and manganese oxides on the surface of supports. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of HMS silica HMS silica was prepared with tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) as the source of silica and dodecylamine (DDA) as the template by assembly pathway of hydrogen-bonding interaction according to the literature procedure [31]. The template was removed by calcinations in air at 550°C for 4h (heating rate 2°C/min). The reaction stoichiometries were as follows: n(TEOS):n(DDA):n(EtOH):n(H2O)=1.00:0.25:15.0:97.2. 2.1.2 Preparation of Co and/or Mn supported HMS catalysts Co–HMS catalysts (Co 2, 4 and 8wt.%) were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation procedure with ethanol solutions of cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O). The concentrations of the impregnating solutions were calculated to obtain 2–8wt.% cobalt in the final catalysts, respectively. Co–HMS catalysts (Co 2 and 4wt.%) were prepared via one-step impregnation. 8%Co–HMS (Co 8wt.%) was prepared via the second impregnation from the calcined 4%Co–HMS above in favor of high dispersion of metal oxides and intact mesostructure. The volume of the impregnation solution of ethanol was equal to the framework pore volume of the supports. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried for 12h in an oven at 80°C, then calcined at 550°C in air for 4h. Mn–HMS catalysts (Mn 2, 4 and 8wt.%) were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation with ethylene glycol solutions of manganese acetate (Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O). Mn–HMS catalysts (Mn 2 and 4wt.%) were prepared via one-step impregnation. The preparation of 8% Mn–HMS was accomplished via the second impregnation from calcined 4%Mn–HMS because of both the solubility limitation of the Mn precursor in the solvent and high dispersion of manganese species. Bimetal-supported Co–Mn–HMS catalysts (Co 4wt.%, Mn 2 and 4wt.%) were prepared via the one-step Mn impregnation from calcined 4%Co–HMS. The catalyst 4%Co–8%Mn–HMS (Co 4wt.%, Mn 8wt.%) was obtained via the second Mn impregnation from calcined 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS. The procedure was the same as Co–HMS catalysts. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Rigaku Rotaflex diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1542nm). The average crystallite size of Co3O4 was calculated according to the Scherrer equation [32] with a (311) peak at 2θ =36.7°. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were performed at −196°C on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 sorptometer. Prior to analysis the samples were outgassed at 150°C and 10−6 Torr for a minimum of 12h. BET surface areas were calculated from the linear part of the BET plot. Pore size distributions were calculated using the adsorption branches of the N2 isotherms and the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra (DR UV–vis spectra) were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-3101PC spectrometer with BaSO4 as a reference and in a reflection mode with a resolution of 1nm. The collected relative reflection intensity (R ∞ = R sample/R reference) was transformed into F(R ∞ ) using the Kubelka–Munk function F(R ∞ )=(1− R ∞ )2/(2R ∞ ). All spectra were plotted in terms of F(R ∞ ) versus wavelength. Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis was carried out on a Cahn TG System 121 thermogravimeter. A 30–40mg of the samples was placed in a small glass basket and heated from the room temperature to 800°C at a heating rate of 5°C/min in air. 2.3 Catalytic reaction and recycling study To test the catalytic activity, reaction tests were carried out in a 25mL glass flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a reflux condenser and a thermometer. In a typical run, 100mg of catalyst was added to the reactor, followed by the addition of 5mmol 4-t-butyltoluene and 6mL acetonitrile and 0.25mmol NHPI as a free radical promoter. The mixture was allowed to equilibrate at reaction temperature of 70°C and O2 with a flow rate of 1.5mL/min was bubbled through the reaction mixture with vigorous stirring. Finally, the reaction mixture was filtered, and the products in the filtrate were identified by mass spectrometry (MS) and analyzed on a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a SPB-20 capillary column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The filtrates were collected after 5h reaction and used to detect the leached Co and Mn ions from solid catalysts into reaction solution. The contents of Co and Mn ions were determined by the elemental analysis which was carried out on a Labtam 8401 inductively coupled plasma spectrometer (ICP). After the first run, the separated catalyst of 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS was filtered, washed with methanol three times, dried at 100°C in an air oven, activated at 550°C for 4h, and used for the subsequent recycling studies and analyzed by UV–vis spectra. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties The low angle XRD patterns of HMS and Co–HMS are shown in Fig. 1 . All the samples exhibited [100] reflections at 2θ of ca.1.5–2.5° indicative of a typical feature of HMS wormhole structure [33,34]. The [100] reflections of Co–HMS slightly shifted to lower diffraction angle compared with the parent HMS, suggesting that the bulk of unit cells increased after introduction of cobalt to HMS, whereas the intensity and shape of [100] reflection for Co–HMS had less change indicating Co–HMS maintained mesoporous structure at the Co content range of 2–8wt.%. Impregnation of Mn on HMS or Co–HMS produced a significant decrease in the ordering of mesostructure of HMS silicas, especially for loading Mn content up to 8wt.%, the framework mesostructure of HMS silicas collapsed completely by judging from the absence of low angle X-ray reflections (not shown). Physical properties of Co and Mn supported HMS silicas are presented in Table 1 . Impregnation of cobalt on HMS silicas resulted in slight decrease in the specific surface areas and pore volumes and an increase in the BJH pore sizes. For Mn-supported catalysts with high Mn content up to 8wt.%, it was possible that a collapse of mesostructure resulted in a partial or even total blockage of the access to pore aperture and decrease of the surface area and pore volume. Hence, manganese had more influence on textural properties of HMS than cobalt. Fig. 2 presents nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of Co and Mn supported catalysts. All the samples exhibited type IV adsorption isotherm patterns of mesostructured materials with the hysteresis loops of type H2 model associated with the textural pores whose capillary condensations were similar to “ink bottle” model [35]. Filling of the framework-confined mesopores occurred in the partial pressure range of 0.2–0.4. The isotherms exhibited an inflection characteristic of capillary condensation within the mesopores when the relative pressure (p/p 0) was higher than 0.2. Adsorption occurred at low relative pressures (p/p 0), i.e., less than 0.2, due to monolayer adsorption of nitrogen on the walls of the mesopores. 3.2 Cobalt and manganese species of the catalysts The diffuse reflectance UV–vis data can provide information regarding the oxidation states of Mn and Co and their chemical environment. The UV–vis spectra for the containing Co and Mn catalysts are displayed in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3A, the absorption bands around 250, 415 and 700nm were observed for all the Co–HMS samples. The bands at around 250nm could be assigned to oxygen-metal charge transfer reflecting the interaction of Co (II) ions with HMS silicas [36]. The intense bands at around 400 and 700nm were assigned to d–d transition of 4T1g (F)→ 4T1g (P) of Co3+ ions in octahedral coordination and 4A2 (F)→ 4T1 (P) of Co2+ ions in tetrahedral coordination in the complex of Co3O4 (Co2+(Co3+)2O4) spinel [37–39], respectively, indicating Co3O4 was the dominant phase in Co-supported HMS silicas. Loading more Co amount up to 8wt.% gave rise to sharp increase in the band intensity at ca. 415 and 700nm compared to 2 and 4%Co–HMS due to the presence of the a high concentration Co3O4 phase. In Fig. 3B, all the Mn–HMS samples displayed an intense band at about 260–286nm caused by the charge transition of O2− →Mn2+ in Mn3O4 complex [40,41]. The increasing of Mn content in the samples gave rise to increase in the band intensity because of the formation of more Mn3O4 phase. The weak shoulders at around 370 and 470nm could be attributed to d–d transitions of the 5B1g → 5B2g and 5B1g → 5Eg of Mn3+ in Mn2O3, and the weak peak at around 640nm corresponded to 6A1g → 4T2g transition of Mn2+ in MnO [42,43]. Therefore, a mixture of Mn3O4, Mn2O3 and MnO was dispersed in Mn–HMS after calcination at 550°C in air. It could be concluded from Fig. 3C (curve g) that Co3O4 particles and a mixture of Mn3O4, Mn2O3 and MnO existed mainly in the fresh calcined 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS. Fig. 4 illustrates the wide angle XRD patterns of HMS and the fresh catalysts of calcined Co and/or Mn-supported HMS in the 2θ range of 20–80°. A broad peak at 2θ ca. 23° for all the samples was observed, which was attributed to the amorphous feature of SiO2. No peaks of Mn3O4, Mn2O3 and MnO could be detected due to the size of crystallites being below the detection limit of the technique, suggesting a very good dispersion of the supported species on the surface of 2, 4 and 8% Mn–HMS [42]. For the Co containing samples, the diffraction peaks at 2θ ca. 31°, 37°, 45°, 60° and 65°, corresponding to (220), (311), (400), (511) and (440) reflections were discerned, which was a typical feature of Co3O4 in agreement with the previous reports [44–46] and the UV–vis data presented above. The diameter of Co3O4 crystallites calculated from the width of the (311) diffraction peak are shown in Table 1. The diameter of Co3O4 crystallites of 8%Co–HMS (21.4nm) was bigger than that of 4%Co–HMS (17.0nm) because of the increase of cobalt amount. 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS (15.8nm) had smaller size of Co3O4 crystallites than 4%Co–HMS (17.0nm). When Mn content was up to 8wt.%, the size of Co3O4 crystallites for 4%Co–8%Mn–HMS prepared via 2 times impregnation of manganese increased to 27.6nm. This may be due to that high Mn amount and more calcination times favor agglomeration of supported cobalt oxide particles. As a result, they made differences in concentration of surface active sites and dispersion for metal oxides. It could be explained why they exhibited different catalytic activities. The thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG–DTA) curves in air for the uncalcined loading 4%Co and 4%Mn HMS silicas are given in Fig. 5 , and the results of the thermal analyses are summarized in Table 2 . Before TG–DTA test, the uncalcined 4%Co–HMS was dried in air at 100°C for 12h and 4%Mn–HMS as-made was vacuumed to remove impregnation solvent of ethylene glycol at 200°C for 4h without calcination. The DTA curve of uncalcined 4%Co–HMS recorded in air displayed the exothermic peaks at 48, 163 and 468°C corresponding to physisorbed water removal, decomposition of supported cobalt nitrate as impregnation precursor [38], and the removal of the structural hydroxyl groups of HMS. The decomposition of cobalt nitrate led to formation of Co3O4, NO2, O2 and H2O as represented in the equation below: 3Co(NO3)2·6H2O=Co3O4 +6NO2 +O2 +18H2O In contrast, the curves of pure Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O used as the precursor of 4%Mn–HMS are also presented in Fig. 5. The decomposition of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O led to formation of a mixture of MnO, Mn3O4, Mn2O3 and MnO2 depending on temperature and concentration of dioxygen, and meanwhile, to release of CO2 and H2O as shown in Eqs. (1)–(4). (1) Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O+4O2 =MnO+4CO2 +3H2O (2) Mn ( CH 3 COO ) 2 4 H 2 O + 4 O 2 + 1 6 O 2 = 1 3 Mn 3 O 4 + 4 CO 2 + 7 H 2 O (3) Mn ( CH 3 COO ) 2 4 H 2 O + 4 O 2 + 1 4 O 2 = 1 2 Mn 2 O 3 + 4 CO 2 + 7 H 2 O (4) Mn ( CH 3 COO ) 2 4 H 2 O + 4 O 2 + 1 2 O 2 = MnO 2 + 4 CO 2 + 7 H 2 O The TGA profile of pure manganese acetate salt exhibited two exothermic effects at 115°C due to the removal of physisorbed water, and at 263°C due to decomposition of acetate anion. A very confined and strong endothermic peak at 313°C and a very weak endothermic peak at 550°C were assigned to phase changes of manganese oxides [47]. The weight loss of Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O was 65.4% at 20–310°C, while the weight increased 2.2% at 310–800°C. The total weight loss was 63.2% at the temperature range between 20 and 800°C. It was noticeable the fact that the total weight loss (63.2%) at 20–800°C was less than the weight loss (65.4%) at 20–310°C, and the weight increased with the increase of combustion temperature at 310–650°C. It could be seen from Eqs. (1) to (4) that the decomposition of 1mol of manganese acetate could produce 1mol of MnO or 1/3mol of Mn3O4 or 1/2mol of Mn2O3 or 1mol of MnO2. Obviously, the manganese oxides with high valencies possess high mass of oxygen atom and high total mass. When combustion temperature was higher than 310°C, manganese oxides with high valencies were formed to bring about the weight increase. So, it was reasonable to conclude that manganese acetate was firstly oxidized to manganese oxides of low valencies, then partially to high valencies as the combustion temperature increased. Thermal analyses of uncalcined 4%Mn–HMS showed intense exothermic peak at ca. 255°C corresponding to the transformation of impregnation precursor into manganese oxides. This peak was approximately in agreement with the peak of decomposition of pure manganese acetate at around 263°C. Besides, the typical exothermic peak at 386°C associated to the removal of the structural hydroxyl groups of HMS silicas. No endothermic peaks at ca. 310°C and 550°C were observed owing to little amount of manganese oxides compared with pure manganese acetate. However, it was also possible that a part of low valency Mn2+ was oxidized to high valencies of Mn3+ or Mn4+ for Mn supported HMS silicas calcined at 550°C according to decomposition of pure manganese acetate at 310–650°C. 3.3 Catalytic properties Table 3 lists the catalytic activity data, together with selectivity for 4-t-butylbenzaldehyde (ArCHO), 4-t-butylbenzyl alcohol (ArCH2OH) and 4-t-butyl-benzyl acid (ArCOOH) in oxidation reaction of 4-t-butyltoluene (ArCH3) with O2 over the catalysts using NHPI, a commercially available compound prepared easily as free radical promoter [8,48]. The actions of NHPI and the catalysts were initially tested. Results showed that ArCH3 was not able to be oxidized by O2 over the catalysts without the help of NHPI suggesting M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) supported on the catalysts could not activate CH of ArCH3 to form of 4-t-butyltoluene radical (ArCH2 ) by hydrogen abstraction due to their low ability of free radical initiation. ArCHO, ArCOOH and small amount of ArCH2OH were detected and 7.2% conversion of ArCH3 was achieved in the blank test using NHPI as radical promoter in the absence of catalyst. This indicated NHPI was an effective radical promoter under heating and stirring. Higher conversions and selectivities to ArCHO were obtained in 4-t-butyltoluene oxidation over the Co and/or Mn supported catalysts as compared to the blank reaction. Therefore, the Co and/or Mn impregnated catalysts exhibited high activity in oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene with dioxygen. Co3O4 [Co3O4 Co2+(Co3+)2O4] and a mixture of MnO, Mn3O4 [Mn3O4 Mn2+(Mn3+)2O4] and Mn2O3 dispersed on the surface of the Co and Mn monometallic or bimetal supported catalysts were responsible for their high activities. The formation of ArCHO, ArCH2OH and ArCOOH would be explained by the following reaction mechanism. The activity of the catalysts decreased according to conversion of ArCH3 in the sequence 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS>4%Co–2%Mn–HMS>4%Co–HMS>8%Co–HMS>8%Mn–HMS>4%Co–8%Mn–HMS>4%Mn–HMS>2%Co–HMS>2%Mn–HMS. The comparison among the catalysts revealed that 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS exhibited the best catalytic performance in the oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene with O2. This could be also most likely due to that 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS catalyst provided a high concentration of surface active sites and high dispersion for oxides of cobalt and manganese based on the forenamed results obtained from XRD, UV–vis and TG/DTA. Generally, the conversion of ArCH3 increased with increasing of the loading-metal amount in the catalysts. The high catalytic activity could be rationalized by more M2+ (Co2+, Mn2+) and/or M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) species supported on the catalysts. However, 4%Co–8%Mn–HMS with maximum loading-metals afforded lower conversion than other Co–Mn–HMS catalysts because of its low dispersion of metal oxides indicating nanoparticle aggregation could result in low catalytic activity. Therefore, both the concentration and dispersion of metal oxides species influenced on the oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene. The selectivities of ArCHO and ArCOOH were higher than that of ArCH2OH indicating the presence of transition metal ions of M2+ (Co2+, Mn2+) and M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) had great influence on the directions of the free radical chain reactions. It could be concluded these ions would inhibit the step (c) to form ArCH2OH and promote ArCHO to convert into ArCOOH by the step (e) according to the following reaction mechanism given. It could be seen from Table 3 that the ArCHO turnover decreased from 11.5 to 6.1mol/mol when loading-Mn amount increased from 2% to 8% because more ArCHO was further oxidized into ArCOOH suggesting that Mn3+ had strong ability to propagate the free radical chains on the basis of the oxidation mechanism of the step (e) below. The similar change trend of ArCHO turnover was observed for the bimetal supported catalysts. Furthermore, Mn-supported HMS catalysts gave lower selectivity of ArCHO than Co–HMS catalysts probably owing to that their faulty framework mesostructure described above hindered the diffusion of both the substrate and the product molecules. Fig. 6 presents the time–dependence curves for oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene over 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS catalyst under the same conditions as in Table 3. The conversion of ArCH3 went up almost linearly with time. Maximal 85.6% conversion of ArCH3 to ArCOOH, ArCHO and ArCH2OH with 89.4%, 9.2% and 1.4% selectivity, respectively, was obtained after 14h reaction. The selectivity of ArCHO was remained at 62.7–67.8% for 5h, but decreased gradually with time. After 5h reaction, it suddenly dropped at over 9h due to further oxidation to ArCOOH. The selectivity of ArCH2OH maitained small amount in 0.4–4.6%. To check the reusability of the catalyst, repeated runs of recovered 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS with the best catalytic activity for oxidation reaction of 4-t-butyltoluene was carried out under the same conditions as Table 3. The recycling result was shown in Fig. 7 . Neither conversion of ArCH3 nor selectivity of ArCHO changed significantly in the recycling experiments indicating 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS was heterogeneous catalyst for recycling. A meager loss in activity was observed after the fourth run suggesting that most of the cobalt and manganese ions were intact in the HMS silicas, which was supported by the UV–vis spectra of the treated catalysts (Fig. 3C). Comparing the treated catalyst of 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS after undergoing the first run and fourth run with the fresh one, the UV–vis absorption bands located at the same wavelength, and no major change in intensity of the bands at ca. 400 and 700nm was observed with a little change in intensity of the bands at around 230–250nm. A very small amount of cobalt (0.28wt.%) and manganese (0.39wt.%) was detected by ICP analysis of the liquid filtrate. Therefore, some leaching might have occurred because of the presence of a small amount of loosely bound cobalt and manganese species in the HMS silicas. 3.4 Reaction mechanism The radical mechanism of oxidation of hydrocarbons is commonly accepted. Free radical is generated by transition metal salts of variable valencies or hydroperoxides or ray radiation, etc. However, in dioxygen oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene, it was difficult for transition metal salts of cobalt and manganese catalysts of variable valencies to make the chain rupture of carbon–hydrogen bonding and to activate dioxygen in mild condition according to the test results above. Based on both the earlier literatures [6,17,39] and our test results, we concluded that the partial oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene (ArCH3) with O2 over Co and/or Mn-supported catalysts using NHPI as free radical promoter proceeded by a free radical mechanism. NHPI was easily converted into phthalimide-N-oxyl (PINO) radicals under heating and stirring, and promoted radical transfer and chain rupture of CH of alkanes. M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) ions supported on the catalysts were able to accelerate NHPI to form PINO radicals. These PINO radicals were eventually responsible for the formation of the products since the hydrogen abstraction from 4-t-butyltoluene by the PINO radicals gave rise to forming 4-t-butyltoluene radicals (ArCH2 ) which were facilely trapped by dioxygen to convert 4-t-butylbenzyl peroxide radicals (ArCH2OO). The 4-t-butylbenzyl peroxide radicals (ArCH2OO) formed the last products of ArCHO and ArCH2OH and ArCOOH depending on the action of M2+ (Co2+, Mn2+) and M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) ions and dioxygen. The oxidation process underwent six steps (a)–(f) as follows: (a) Formation of phthalimide-N-oxyl (PINO) radicals (b) Formation of ArCH2 and ArCH2OO radicals Ar C H 2 + O 2 → ArCH 2 OO ArCH 2 OO + ArCH 3 → ArCH 2 OOH + Ar C H 2 (c) Formation of 4-t-butylbenzyl alcohol (ArCH2OH) ArCH 2 OOH + ArCH 3 → ArCH 2 OH + O H + Ar C H 2 (d) Formation of 4-t-butylbenzaldehyde (ArCHO) ArCH 2 OO + M 2 + → ArCHO + OH − + M 3 + ArCH 2 OH + M 2 + → ArCHO + H 2 O + M 3 + (e) Formation of 4-t-butyl-benzyl acid (ArCOOH) ArCHO + M 3 + → Ar C O + H + + M 2 + Ar C O + O 2 → ArCOOO ArCOOO + ArCH 3 → ArCOOOH + Ar C H 2 ArCOOOH + M 2 + → ArCOO + OH − + M 3 + ArCOO + ArCH 3 → ArCOOH + Ar C H 2 (f) Termination of the radical chains 2 ArCH 2 OO → ArCHO + ArCH 2 OH + O 2 Generally, the mechanism for autoxidations via a radical chain process consists of initiation, propagation, and termination steps. In this case, the steps (a) and (b) were chain initiation process, and the steps of (c)–(e) were the chain propagations. The radical chains were terminated mainly by coupling of two peroxyl radicals besides other factors such as its reaction with vessel walls or solvent. The step (c) to formation of ArCH2OH was difficult to take place in presence of PINO radicals and M2+ ions because ArCH3 was facilely trapped to form 4-t-butyltoluene radicals (ArCH2 ) by PINO radicals and ArCH2OOH was easy to be reduced to form ArCHO. In the step (e), ArCHO was further oxidized into ArCOOH with the help of metal ions of M2+ and M3+. 4 Conclusions The above study showed that the Co and Mn supported HMS catalysts prepared by conventional incipient wetness impregnation using cobalt nitrate and manganese acetate as precursors and calcined at 550°C in air maintained the characteristics of mesoporous materials with dispersion of dominant species of Co3O4 particles and a mixture of manganese oxides. The Co and Mn supported HMS materials efficiently catalyzed the selective oxidation of 4-t-butyltoluene to 4-tert-butylbenzaldehyde in addition to by-products of 4-tert-butylbenzyl alcohol and 4-tert-butylbenzyl acid proceeding by a free radical mechanism under mild reaction conditions using NHPI as free radical promoter. The 4%Co–4%Mn–HMS as heterogeneous catalyst could be considered viable alternatives due to its easy recovery and recycling. coredata.dc:description: Monometallic cobalt and manganese, and their bimetal-supported hexagonal mesoporous silicas (HMS) prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation using cobalt nitrate and manganese acetate as precursors, and ethanol and ethylene glycol as impregnation solvents, respectively, were examined as catalysts for partial oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene with dioxygen as oxidizing agent in acetonitrile solvent. The catalysts were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm, diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy and thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis. The introduction of cobalt oxides to HMS kept complete mesostructure of HMS supports, high specific surface areas and big pore volumes. The dominant phase of Co3O4 was detected in the Co–HMS materials calcined at 550°C. A mixture of manganese oxides (MnO, Mn2O3, Mn3O4) was dispersed on the Mn–HMS catalysts after calcination at 550°C in the air. The bimetal-supported Co–Mn–HMS with loading 4wt.% of Co and Mn exhibited the best catalytic performance in the oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene with O2, and gave a conversion of 43.7% of 4-tert-butyltoluene and maximal yield of 27.4% of 4-tert-butylbenzaldehyde in a reaction time of 5h in liquid phase under mild condition. A high concentration and dispersion of M2+ (Co2+, Mn2+) and M3+ (Co3+, Mn3+) ions on catalysts were responsible for high catalytic performance in the oxidation reaction via a free-radical chain promoted by N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI). The four consecutive cycles revealed that the cobalt and manganese species supported on HMS provided a possibility for the heterogeneous oxidation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic oxidation of 4-tert-butyltoluene over cobalt and manganese supported hexagonal mesoporous silicas as heterogeneous catalysts
